awd_titl_txt: WPUNJ Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase II
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a well-documented need for competent, confident, and committed STEM teachers to serve in high-need school districts.  Through this Phase 2 Noyce project, William Paterson University will produce twenty-four well-qualified STEM teachers who inspire learning and who are committed to teaching in high-needs districts.  Scholarships will be provided to qualifying undergraduate STEM majors for their final two years of undergraduate study.  The project will also offer opportunities for STEM majors to be exposed to teaching as a career through paid summer internships, tutoring, and/or teaching assistantships.  William Paterson University (WPU) will partner with Mercer County Community College (MCCC) to develop certified STEM teachers who possess at least a baccalaureate degree in mathematics, chemistry, earth science, biology, or integrated math and science, which is a STEM major in the College of Science and Health at WPU.   This Phase 2 project, funded by the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, will also conduct research using a quasi-experimental design involving Phase 1 and Phase 2 Noyce Scholars to identify variables that lead them to become teachers, as well as variables that lead to their success in teaching in high need urban schools.  Comparison groups of pre-service and in-service teachers at WPU, who are not part of the Noyce program, will be used.  

This project will be effective in recruiting and retaining new high-performing teachers who inspire STEM learning, thrive in high-need partner districts, and support others to do the same.  The project aims to increase the number of STEM teacher candidates who become certified at WPU from 10% to 20% over the next five years by providing scholarships to qualifying WPU students and by providing opportunities for 12-20 STEM majors to be exposed to teaching as a career through summer internships, tutoring, supplemental instructional leadership or study group leader experiences.  WPU will work in partnership with MCCC to recruit 3-5 STEM transfer students who are qualified for the Noyce Scholarship annually and recruit 6-10 qualified candidates who will enter the College of Education as STEM teacher candidates annually.  The project will ensure that teacher candidates are capable of being inspiring teachers by enrolling in a science or mathematics pedagogy course that focuses on cooperative, collaborative, and inquiry-based methods, contributing to an annual chronicle of STEM lesson plans, and by conducting classroom observations of Phase I graduates in high need districts prior to graduation.  Teacher candidates will spend their clinical practicum as well as their student teaching semester in a high-need urban professional development school.  Faculty advisors, teacher-mentors and peer-mentors will be assigned to scholarship recipients during their junior and senior years and mentoring will continue into their first two years of teaching.  The project will also support scholarship students through a project identity and social media forum.  It is anticipated that three recruitment pools will increase as a result of this project:  the number of STEM majors graduating with teacher certification, the number of minority STEM majors graduating with teacher certification, and the number of transfer STEM majors graduating with teacher certification.  Ultimately, this project will contribute twenty-four new STEM teachers, many of them from underrepresented groups in STEM, as well as build knowledge related to STEM teacher recruitment for high need districts through 4-year and 2-year college partnerships.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: WILLIAM PATERSON UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

por.por_cntn:
The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at William Paterson University (WPU) Phases I and II helped train 63 STEM teachers who are working in high needs districts with another 4 who are expected to be certified in the next year. These are math or science teachers who are in demand and may have never applied to a high needs district without the Noyce requirement. Based on the PIs' research, Noyce participants are inspired to teach in a high-needs, urban setting and some feel like they are "giving back".

The Noyce II grant project required that we also report on Noyce I.  We can report that 85 percent of Noyce I and II participants are certified and teaching in a high needs district. These teachers state that they believe they are successful in the classroom. They note their success (through gaining tenure or receiving high observation scores) as well as their students' success (through student grades and interest in STEM subjects).

Providing students with inquiry-based coursework was a priority throughout the Noyce II grant. The College of Education reviewed and modified its courses so that all curriculum is inquiry-based and provides students with assessment procedures aligned with the outcomes of inquiry. The curriculum requires a content pedagogy course that focuses on cooperative, collaborative, and inquiry-based methods. One of the outcomes of this course is an inquiry lesson plan. Noyce students do very well in this course.

The Noyce grant expects projects to develop and offer academic courses and early clinical teaching experiences designed to prepare undergraduates to teach STEM in elementary and secondary schools served by a high-need population. To better address the issue of inspiration in high-needs districts the PI decided to explore the experiences and pedagogical practices of Noyce I science and math teachers in urban schools. Her research focused on the impact of science and math teachers relative to K-12 student performance and asks: How do middle and high school math and science teachers inspire math and science learning? Using structured interviews, the team attempted to identify and measure teacher awareness, attitudes knowledge and skills around cultural competence. While the population of Noyce teachers participating in the research was relatively small, outcomes suggest that teachers who are trained to understand cultural differences and inquiry-based learning can be inspiring STEM teachers who believe they are making a difference and advocating for change in their classrooms and schools. But they need resources and support.

There are several broader impacts of this grant project.  Based on her research, and in an effort to provide all teacher candidates with the skills and understanding of teaching in high-needs districts, the PI collaborated with the Africana-World Studies program at the university to create a 12-credit undergraduate Certificate in Cultural Competence.  The Undergraduate Faculty Council recommended and approved this 12-credit Certificate in Cultural Competence in the spring 2020 semester.

During Noyce II, the PIs provided scholars with resources that helped them understand how to infuse social justice into the science curriculum and make it more applicable and real for students. Teacher candidates used these resources in inquiry lesson plans focused on environmental justice and climate change.  Book discussion groups were also formed with STEM majors and STEM teacher candidates.

Another outcome of the Noyce II project was a stronger relationship with administrative departments for future grant proposals.   For example, our notion of culturally responsive mentoring in our latest S-STEM project was inspired from collaborations with the academic support offices at WPU via the Noyce project.  We also found that direct relationships are needed with financial aid, admissions, and transfer offices.

Overall, the Noyce Scholarship Program Phase II, was fairly successful. The Noyce II project awarded 40 scholarships to 14 undergraduate candidates. Nine of the 14 scholars are certified and teaching in a high needs school district. The other scholars are still enrolled in the STEM teaching program, and one decided to pursue graduate work. The recent pandemic considerably hampered project objectives.

The Noyce scholarship program at WPU was guided by its goal of addressing the critical shortage of highly effective elementary and secondary science and mathematics teachers in high-needs schools in New Jersey. Noyce scholarships provided the financial assistance students needed to have a double major and participants found that Noyce funding eased the financial stress of becoming a teacher. Furthermore, the curriculum changes and opportunities around inquiry, cultural competence, and social justice science teaching are a clear indication that the Noyce II project made a significant impact at WPU and other educational communities in New Jersey.


Last Modified: 12/06/2021
Modified by: Djanna A Hill
